Fame is often a case the right person being the extremely unlikely right place at the right time. This is truer in Mark Wahlberg's case than for anyone else. He didn't work hard. How a kid from Boston previously convicted of assault (after actually committing a series of deplorable hate crimes) not even 2 years later launched a successful rap career is a complete mystery. Nobody in a similar situation should expect that this is going to happen to them at all through any kind of hard word, luck or otherwise. It happened to Marky Mark because there was some demand for terrible white rappers then, he looked good with his shirt off, and some producer really wanted to shove the racist white boy rapper thing so hard that he put more money behind promoting that than anything else that year. When you are Mark Wahlberg it must the most extreme case of survivor bias. It feels like you turned your life around and changed, but your success was such a snowballs chance in hell that its probabitlity can't even be calculated. And randomly stumbling into a fortune will make anyone change into a "better" person. Unfortunately nobody is, has, or will again rise to fame in this exact manor except for Mark Wahlberg.
